If you're looking for a fun, rewarding team-based FPS, look elsewhere. 

Overwatch was probably my most played game in 2016 and 2017. Got every achievement (Prior to Doomfist) on the PS4 version and had an absolute ball with it. I'm not sure what was going on in the heads of the developers between then and now. 
But what is it now? A ton of false promises to distract us from the many awful things Blizzard has done. Heck, I'd even be able to live with that if the game was fun to make progress on, but now it's just battlepasses and other predatory forms of microtransactions. Every new hero use to be free so that nobody was left in the dust when it came to learning how they worked, and thus learning how to counter them. Now, the only way to learn is by forking over some cash.

Overwatch 1 had lootboxes, yes, but at least you can play to earn those back then and still get neat skins and whatnot without spending a nickle. 

This game really is just a shadow of what it use to be. More content won't fix the game.
I've been playing since just after the launch of the original Overwatch. Love the game

There are certainty valid criticisms of Blizzards mishandling of Overwatch 2 and the community is right to express them. However, bringing the game to steam is not one of those. Steam reviews are a place to recommend or criticize a game for the benefit of other players. Using it as an opportunity to air every grievance only hurts the games chances on the platform. You'll most likely see an abundance of detailed negativity directed at the choices the development team at Blizzard have made over the past year or so. Given that, I'm going to do something crazy and focus on the merits of the game itself.

At its core, Overwatch 2 remains a fun, competitive experience, with more heart and personality than just about any other competitive game out there. There are issues to be sure however, Overwatch remains a game I care about and want to see succeed. I've been playing Overwatch on and off since it first come out back in May of 2016. Although I have taken years long breaks from the game, I've managed to see it both at its peak and at it's absolute lowest of low points. My hour count might be on the higher side then most of the games casual audience however, I do play the game very casually. I'm not someone that cares much about my rank in 'Competitive' (ranked) modes and I mainly stick to the 'Quick Play' or the varied 'Arcade' modes. I play the game for fun, not for the thrill of competition or sport. No shade at the people that do it's just not my style.

For new players Overwatch offers a wide range of characters, each with their own unique abilities, competing in a variety of game modes. There is a high skill ceiling do to the games focus on character strengths and weaknesses. Similar to a fighting game the games depth lies within the interplay between the different characters and their abilities. Learning the ins and outs of of these systems is where the bulk of interest in the game lies for me. This can be understandably overwhelming for someone jumping in for the first time but a lot of that is alleviated by the games smart controls. Instead of a game like Street Fighter that use lengthy, button spaghetti to dull out attacks all of Overwatchs controls are unified across characters. Single presses of E, Shift, Right Click, Left Click, are all you really need to unleash your characters abilities. Adding to this, every character is made to feel unique. They are expressive, detailed, and feel like real characters in a world instead of the cookie cutter, role filling characters so prevalent in other competitive games. 

The free to play aspect brings a long some undesired outcomes relating to monetization. However, the core gameplay still remains just as fun as it ever was for me. I'll still take long breaks here and there but it will always be a game I return to and check up on. Even if the game is in a troubling spot right now I have faith the game will be better for it in the long run. The potential is definitely there and I give more credit to the devs than most other people are seemingly willing to. 

You should try the game, no other competitive game plays quite like it. Plus it's free, and for what's on offer here I think that's a pretty good deal.

This game is the absolute pinnacle of garbage. Quitting this game made me a better person, let me get and keep my girlfriend, made me happier overall and honestly improved my life. The magic of the first year of Overwatch 1 died so long ago, this is just a cash-grab that will be peddled forever. Do not waste your time on this game. Go play TF2.
